stream_context.summary: Kaze prepares the upcoming demo build while prototyping and polishing a late-game “space/arcade” area: fixing rendering/texture issues on real N64, tuning performance, implementing a low-gravity zone, and redesigning warp platforms to avoid Mario transparency conflicts. He also discusses long-term plans for a legally distinct standalone version (asset/IP swap) potentially sold on Steam via N64 Recomp, plus practical constraints around physical N64 cartridges.
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains concrete technical decisions that affect the whole project (removing Mario transparency, warp animation approach, low-gravity implementation, N64 performance targets), plus revealing business/legal thoughts about an original-IP standalone release alongside RTYI.

findings.summary: Kaze says he was getting the demo “mostly release-ready” off stream, and confirms a secret “Delfino” level is planned for the demo but expects most players won’t unlock it.
He explicitly states a physical N64 cartridge release would require rights to Super Mario 64, which he does not have, framing physical release as legally blocked for the RTYI build.
findings.quote: To make a physical card, I would need the rights to Super Mario 64 first. I don't have them currently.

findings.summary: Kaze floats a concrete contingency plan: release RTYI as a Mario-based hack, but also build a second version that is ~90% the same content with Nintendo IP replaced by original characters/assets, with movement changed enough to function as a distinct game that he could legally own and potentially sell on Steam (possibly using N64 Recomp).

He acknowledges there is still original Nintendo code in the project but says he plans to replace it, partly for legal cleanliness but also because he considers the original code inefficient and hard to work with.
findings.quote: There is some original Nintendo code left, but I am planning to replace it. Not even because I want to replace all the Nintendo code, just because the code is complete dog ass.

findings.summary: Performance target framing: he treats 60 FPS on Steam Deck as a solid goal and anything beyond as “luxury,” while showing a heavy view in the level dipping to ~22–25 FPS and judging it acceptable for N64-era expectations.
findings.quote: 60 on Steam Deck is a good target. Anything more than that should be considered a luxury.

findings.summary: He demonstrates testing on real N64 hardware during stream; the build is “not very stable at the moment” and crashes, but he considers it fixable.
findings.quote: It's not very stable at the moment, but don't worry about that. It's fixable.

findings.summary: A rendering bug investigation reveals he adjusted the wrong asset/config because he built levels in reverse order; fixing the correct lens flare definition restores intended intensity control.
findings.quote: I know exactly what it is. I edited the wrong one. This is unbelievable. Because I made the levels in reverse order.

findings.summary: He describes difficulty philosophy: he likes placing extremely hard optional challenges late in the game, but recognizes players often encounter them earlier than intended and then blame the game, so he wants stronger gating or presentation to prevent accidental frustration.
findings.quote: I like putting super hard things in my games... The problem is that a lot of the time players do encounter it... so I wanna prevent that.

findings.summary: Warp platform design changes: Mario transparency during fading warps breaks materials/coloring in the new rendering setup, so he decides to disable Mario transparency and instead animate the warp by scaling/transform-matrix manipulation to avoid transparency pipelines.
findings.quote: My life would be easier if we disabled the ability of Mario to go transparent... So instead of this, I think we're going to use a scale animation where Mario just scales into the ground.

findings.summary: He notes a micro-optimization mindset: enabling certain flags adds extra processing, so he removes/relocates a warp-related flag to avoid unnecessary per-frame overhead.
He implements a low-gravity zone as a placeable area effect in the space/arcade level, implying the engine now supports localized gravity changes that can be moved around during level iteration.
findings.quote: And there we go. Low gravity's on. It's as simple as that.

findings.summary: Kaze outlines his level-building workflow: define an outline, implement needed actors/mechanics, then rapidly rearrange platforms and iterate by play-feel—keep what’s fun, discard what isn’t, then polish.
findings.quote: Then I just start moving it around and see what's fun... we keep whatever turned out to be fun. And we discard what wasn't fun.

findings.summary: He indicates Biobak is reworking Kaze’s textures/art, so Kaze tries to avoid spending time on texture polish that will be replaced anyway—showing a dependency where art pass is planned downstream of gameplay/structure.
findings.quote: Considering Biobak is reworking all my stuff anyway. I should just leave it to him.

findings.summary: Memory/ROM scope: he states the game will be “almost 64 megabytes,” and he intends to use the full budget to improve quality; he also reacts to finding “a full megabyte” of RAM as a helpful surprise, suggesting ongoing memory reclamation to fit N64 constraints.
findings.quote: The game will be almost 64 megabytes... I can use all of them. So I'm gonna use all of them to make the game better.

findings.summary: Demo timing constraint: he suggests the demo likely won’t be for Christmas because another creator (“Robot”) is releasing something around then and Kaze doesn’t want to overshadow it.
findings.quote: It's probably not going to be for Christmas because Robot is releasing this for like Christmas and I don't want to ruin his release.

biobak.summary: Kaze repeatedly frames Biobak as the upcoming owner of the texture/art rework pass, influencing Kaze’s decision to avoid premature texture iteration and focus on mechanics/actors first.

zeina.summary: Zeina contributes environment art (carpet texture and associated visual style elements); Kaze showcases it as a key piece of the level’s “arcade/cinema lobby” vibe and responds to her questions on stream, highlighting active at-home collaboration.
zeina.quote: What do you think of the carpet that Zeina made? Pretty cool, eh?

zeina.summary: Brief domestic snapshot: Kaze mentions the baby is sleeping with the chat participant (context suggests Zeina/household), implying the team’s development cadence is intertwined with parenting routines.

findings.summary: Lilaa repeatedly prompts discussion about distribution/Steam vs N64 differences and player accessibility; Kaze concedes that a Steam release of a standalone version could reduce the barrier of users thinking they must be “tech nerds” to play a Mario 64 hack.

Kaze reacts to Malon and Brodude’s Kickstarter performance (high funding and large average pledge), calling it surprising evidence of demand for N64-style projects and a data point he wants to remember.

Suggests adding CRTs with GIFs around the casino/arcade space; Kaze treats it as aligned with his intended vibe and adds it to the set of decorative elements to build before deeper platforming design.

key_stories.title: Planning a legally ownable standalone version alongside RTYI
key_stories.summary: While preparing the RTYI demo, Kaze explores a parallel plan: keep RTYI as a Mario-based ROM hack, but also create a near-equivalent version with original IP assets and adjusted movement so it can be sold more easily (e.g., on Steam). He frames this as hypothetical but grounded in accessibility and legal practicality.
key_stories.challenge: RTYI’s Mario IP blocks straightforward commercial distribution (Steam) and physical cartridge releases, and some players may be hesitant to set up a Mario 64 hack.
key_stories.process: Kaze considers swapping Nintendo IP for original characters/assets, changing movement/feel to differentiate, and leveraging N64 Recomp for a Steam build; he also mentions gradually replacing remaining Nintendo code due to quality and ownership concerns.
key_stories.outcome: No commitment yet, but the idea becomes a concrete strategic option Kaze is actively evaluating based on audience interest and feasibility.
key_stories.key_quote: What if, along with RTYI, I also release a game that is 90% the same content, but we replace all the Nintendo IP with our own?

key_stories.title: Warp platforms break when Mario fades: replacing transparency with matrix/scale animation
key_stories.summary: Kaze wants warp platforms with a flashy dissolve/spin effect, but discovers the traditional fading warp makes Mario transparent and causes rendering/material issues in his updated pipeline. He chooses an alternate approach that avoids transparency entirely.
key_stories.challenge: Mario transparency during warp interferes with the project’s materials and color handling (“Nth color”), breaking visuals.
key_stories.process: He identifies the transparency flag/behavior as the root cause, disables Mario transparency, and implements a scale-based animation by manipulating the transformation matrix and object flags to achieve a warp feel without transparency overhead.
key_stories.outcome: Warp effect becomes visually acceptable and more compatible with the custom rendering setup; he continues refining timing (early frames too slow).
key_stories.key_quote: My life would be easier if we disabled the ability of Mario to go transparent... we don't use Mario's transparency, so there's no point to it.

key_stories.title: Fixing a lens flare/bridge issue caused by editing the wrong level (reverse build order)
key_stories.summary: While tuning lens flare intensity and investigating a visibility/texture issue, Kaze realizes his change isn’t taking effect because he edited the wrong configuration. The confusion stems from building levels in reverse order.
key_stories.challenge: Lens flare intensity changes appear ineffective; bridge/texture behavior seems inconsistent between editor and in-game testing.
key_stories.process: He traces usage of the intensity parameter, tests extreme values, then recognizes he modified the wrong asset due to reversed level order. He switches to the correct definition and the control works.
key_stories.outcome: Lens flare becomes tunable again, and he sets a more reasonable intensity value for the area’s look.
key_stories.key_quote: I edited the wrong one... Because I made the levels in reverse order.

key_stories.title: Turning a space/arcade concept into a playable course via actor-first iteration
key_stories.summary: Kaze frames the current space/arcade area as an early version where “everything is missing” besides core mechanics and set dressing. He moves from visuals (carpet, bridge materialization, pixel-art lights) into systems (low gravity, moving platforms) before committing to final platform layouts.
key_stories.challenge: Designing fun platforming in a visually busy, unconventional space with many experimental elements is difficult; Kaze worries about wasting time polishing assets that may be cut.
key_stories.process: He programs needed objects (bumpers, platforms, asteroids, low-gravity zones), drops in rough platforms, plans eight red coins (mostly below a structure), and iterates by rearranging geometry to find what feels good.
key_stories.outcome: Low-gravity zones are functioning and placeable; he ends stream ready to shift into deeper platforming design once a few remaining art pieces are finished.
key_stories.key_quote: We need to somehow turn this into a fun gameplay.

open_questions.topic: Demo scope, gating, and release timing
open_questions.context: Kaze says the demo is being prepared off stream, includes a secret Delfino level most players won’t unlock, and likely won’t release at Christmas to avoid clashing with “Robot’s” release.
questions: What exactly is planned to be in the demo (courses, side levels, overworld access, secrets), and what is cut?
How will the Delfino secret be unlocked, and why is it important to include as a ‘hidden’ demo feature?
Who is ‘Robot,’ what are they releasing, and how do you decide when to avoid competing releases?
What milestones need to be hit before you feel safe publishing a public demo build?

open_questions.topic: Standalone original-IP version feasibility (asset swap + movement changes)
open_questions.context: Kaze proposes a ~90% content-equivalent version replacing Nintendo IP and adjusting movement, potentially sold on Steam using N64 Recomp, to reduce friction and legal risk.
questions: How far did you take this plan beyond a thought experiment—any prototypes, character concepts, or pipeline tests?
What would you change mechanically to ensure it feels like its own game, not just a reskin?
Would the original-IP version ship alongside RTYI or later, and how would you message that to fans?
What does ‘legally own it’ mean to you here—assets only, code, branding, or the full product identity?

open_questions.topic: Replacing remaining Nintendo code (quality vs legal motivation)
open_questions.context: Kaze calls Nintendo’s original code inefficient/ugly and says he plans to replace remaining original code; he also discusses unavoidable low-level OS/CPU details (cache ops, CP0 count register).
questions: Which parts of the codebase are still original Nintendo code today, and what’s the replacement roadmap?
How much of this effort is driven by performance/maintainability versus legal/ethical considerations?
What specific subsystems were the worst offenders for cycles/inefficiency, and what did you gain by rewriting them?
Where do you draw the line between ‘must stay low-level’ and ‘can be made cleaner in C’?

open_questions.topic: N64 hardware stability and crash debugging
open_questions.context: Kaze boots the project on a real N64, shows it running at variable frame rates, then the game crashes and he says it’s not stable yet but fixable.
questions: What are the most common crash causes on real hardware right now (memory, RSP/RDP edge cases, timing)?
How do you reproduce and debug hardware-only crashes versus emulator-only glitches?
What tools/logging do you rely on when diagnosing N64 crashes in RTYI?
What ‘stability bar’ must the demo meet before release?

open_questions.topic: Performance targets across Steam, Steam Deck, and real N64
open_questions.context: Kaze frames 60 FPS on Steam Deck as a good target, shows worst-case views in the 22–25 FPS range, and mentions limiting FPS can make drops less noticeable.
questions: What is your performance budget philosophy for N64: minimum FPS, acceptable drops, and where you’ll trade visuals for speed?
How do you test and compare performance across emulators, Steam builds, and original hardware?
Do you design levels around camera angles to avoid worst-case overdraw/visibility spikes?

open_questions.topic: Course 15 space/arcade design goals and late-game placement
open_questions.context: Kaze calls the area early, lists planned set dressing (arcade building, beams, pixel arts), red coin placement ideas, and says designing platforming here will be unusually hard.
questions: Why is this course thematically ‘space/arcade,’ and what emotion or story beat should it land in the overall game arc?
What are the core mechanics of this course (low gravity, bumpers, flippers, beams), and what is the intended player learning curve?
How will you prevent visual noise from harming readability and platforming clarity?
What does success look like for this course compared to earlier ones (Course 1 callback)?

open_questions.topic: Warp platform animation direction and tech constraints
open_questions.context: Kaze wants warps that spin/distort/dissolve, but disables transparency and uses scaling/matrix effects for compatibility and speed.
questions: What final visual language do you want for warps across the whole game—consistent style or per-course variants?
How did disabling Mario transparency affect other features (power-ups, invisibility-style effects, cutscenes)?
What were the alternative solutions you rejected (shader-like tricks, dithering, model variants), and why?

open_questions.topic: Playtesting approach (private tester loops vs public demo)
open_questions.context: Kaze says he often sends demos to a single person repeatedly for feedback, calling it essentially playtesting, and separately endorses demos as good for collecting data.
questions: Who is the recurring ‘one person’ tester, and what makes their feedback uniquely valuable?
What kind of data/feedback do you actually collect from demos—difficulty spikes, navigation confusion, bugs, performance?
When do you choose private iterative testing versus opening it to a wider public demo audience?

open_questions.topic: Memory/ROM budget and the ‘found 1 MB’ surprise
open_questions.context: Kaze references needing to free up the “last megabyte of RAM” and says finding a full megabyte was a nice surprise; he also says the game will be almost 64 MB.
questions: Where did the extra 1 MB come from—what was optimized or removed to reclaim it?
How close are you to the real limits on N64 for this project (RAM, ROM, microcode/task limits)?
What content is most memory-expensive (textures, audio, geometry, custom systems) and how do you prioritize?
